main_text: I have been working at AppDynamics full-time for more than 5 years
pros: I joined AppD when it was a rocket ship ~5 years ago and have experienced the great and the challenged here. The great has far outweighed our challenges and much of that is because of the people. Quite simply, good people come and go, but a quality company like AppD(and Cisco) tends to attract some of the best. This means that you're very infrequently the "smartest" person in the room and there is incredible opportunity for growth personally and professionally. There are very few days that go by where I am not learning something new or watching people blossom here. That just does not happen at every job and it's something I appreciate greatly! Additionally, while the people are great and one of the reasons I've stuck around, I'm still here mainly because the software works. On the sales side, I've listened to stories of and experienced working for companies that had subpar offerings. They are hard to believe in and it's really hard to sell when you don't believe in the core component of your job. On a weekly basis, I get to see us solve business critical problems that our competition just can't. Trust me when I say that drives you to get the message out and help your customers. Finally, the acquisition by Cisco has worked out very well. They have a very people first approach across the board which is great (especially during the interesting times with COVID19). I glad to be working for a company that has an appreciation for their talent.
cons: You will work, a lot. That is true of any job that has a rewarding experience, but you will be challenged in ways you have not been before. If you don't want that, it may not be the right job for you.

main_text: I have been working at AppDynamics full-time for more than a year
pros: The company is changing! Yes, this is a good thing, don't let the 5+ year employees stuck in their way dissuade you. Change is good, change brings opportunity - both for individual contributors and the company as a whole. AppDynamics is consistently breaking records, growing revenue, and outperforming the competition. The product has evolved far past "pure APM" and provides true value at both the IT and business level. -Accelerated career growth -Benefits: weekly massage, snacks/drinks, multiple catered meals, Cisco stock program, 401k match, health benefits, legal benefits, free therapy, etc. -Ability to run your own business and think like an entrepreneur, all ideas are considered -Cisco rated #1 place to work -Cisco ownership - all of the perks, none of the cons. Cisco stays hands-off AppD's culture, but provides tons of financial resources for R&D, headcount, etc. -Cisco's vision for the future is increasingly based upon AppD's successes and culture -Work/life balance is highly encouraged -Fantastic teams to be apart of, highly collaborative, intelligent people
cons: Have to abide by Cisco's annual evaluation/raise cycle, maximum raise percentage cap, promotions and raises aren't quite as easy or frequent to come by as when AppD was its own company. Pay is competitive but arguably has room to grow - lots of reps have left to competitors or similar companies in the space to make more money, but that's typical in the sales world.

review_title: AppDynamics allows gender discrimination and sexual harassment if you’re a leader
main_text: I worked at AppDynamics full-time for more than 5 years
pros: Work-Life balance, good benefits and perks, important product, industry leader, mostly good people.
cons: A well-known, with the knowledge of his boss, took calculated advantage of a direct report by having an extramarital affair and then derailing her career when he was done with her, all while concessions were made for him to continue his career track. He forced her off the team to a different role that was not related to her desired and successful career track, causing her a lot if distress, ultimately leading to her resignation. She was pressured by him to not attend company events, be in HQ the same time as him, etc. Throughout this time, he was very vocal to the rest of team abut his intentions and bragged about his "accomplishment". He intimidated other team members to keep quiet and even lied to HR about the relationship dates as to appear he was following protocol, even though he was with her way before he reported it. This issue has caused a lot of morale issues on our team as this was flaunted right in front of us, causing many of us to quit or start considering quitting. This was reported to HR by her with no actions taken by the company. I resigned yesterday and reported this as well, but I'm skeptical any actions will be taken. Once the Director and his boss caught wind of me talking to HR, they had me walked out of the building by HR, even though I still had a week left. That's what over 5 years of dedicated service to AppDynamics gets you. It's clear that this kind of behavior, especially in this cultural climate, is inexcusable. AppDynamics cares more about sales numbers than doing what is right by its employees, especially ones with limited power. This is not only gender discrimination, but also shows a clear lack of integrity by a company who consistently advertises their focus on culture, diversity, and woman in technology. It's no wonder there aren't more woman working in tech.

review_title: One Of Those Special Organizations You Get The Privileged to Work In
main_text: I have been working at AppDynamics full-time for more than 3 years
pros: I have had the opportunity to work in many organizations throughout my career and have been very blessed with some amazing opportunities. With that being said, there are very few companies where you can say that you are working with the best, have an amazing set of solutions to sell, and that every day you learn and are pushed to the next level by your peers. I had that experience at Mercury Interactive and when I left I once felt that I would be spending the rest of my career searching for that again. Until I found AppDynamics. AppDynamics is truly a special place with a team atmosphere and has some of the best of the best people and solutions you will ever work with. I have never worked harder, learned more, or had more success than I have here. We have a world class sales process that if followed properly proves to our customers the amazing value of our solutions and drives that value after the sale to assure satisfaction and growth of the solution and its usage. We have an excellent engineering and product management staff that focuses on delivering high quality solutions that customers need. Even Cisco's acquisition of AppDynamics, which I was concerned could quickly become a negative, has actually turned into a great positive. Their tendency to provide autonomy to AppDynamics while still giving us the warm hug and support of a huge corporate giant has been well... great!
cons: From a cultural perspective I always chafed at tendency for many especially in the corporate office to want o sugar coat everything. When I initially joined it wasn't appropriate to point out that we weren't perfect and that we had many things to improve. With many changes at the top including the hiring of David Wadhwani that seems to have changed and we are much more accepting of our faults. I'm very proud to see AppDynamics mature as an organization and realize that there was never any magical pixie dust making us great, it was and is great people and hard work that got us where we are and where we will go.

review_title: Depending on what you're looking for, could be great...
main_text: I worked at AppDynamics full-time for more than 3 years
pros: - Leader in the APM space *along with Dynatrace and others who are catching up - Leadership team (CEO, CRO, VP of Sales, etc) are A-Players, world-class leaders - In "most" cases you are treated with respect and once earned, trusted to do your job (i.E., run your individual franchise, drive revenue) - Training, resources (SE's, $, marketing, etc) all available, there's nothing you can think of asking for that they wouldn't at least consider providing if it means helping you drive revenue - Work hard, play hard, realizing that's cliche, it truly is the case, however. You are required to work your tail off and the upside could potentially be exponential. More $1m earners than I've ever seen at a single place in my career. - Generally speaking, most people and leaders want to help and access to C suite, product folks, people that can help de-risk and drive a campaign forward are there.
cons: - APM is becoming a commodity, with a race to the bottom from a pricing standpoint. Differentiation is becoming difficult to position and I think AppD has struggled with the messaging and application of BiQ. - It's still a PTC, BMC BladeLogic boys club - Feast or famine is pretty common. You'll either crush your # or struggle to grind it out to get to 60-80% ote. This is a combination of things but they have hired significantly and you need customers with transactional businesses, pain, etc. Not all customers in your assigned territory will fit this description. - Like anywhere, favoritism and politics exist here no question. - Heavy KPI, metric-driven day-to-day, I found this to be helpful but for many, I could see it being not their cup of tea.

review_title: A sales driven company that lacks innovation
main_text: I worked at AppDynamics full-time
pros: This is a great place to work for anyone in sales or straight out of college; not so much for experienced professionals. You get catered lunches and reasonable benefits.
cons: This a company that's being anchored by the sales team and CRO organization. Product Management, Marketing, Support, HR, and Operations are not valued. When the founder left, several engineers left as well which led to lack of innovation. The company produces new functionality that's driven by Gartner or a competition. The company is now comfortable having access to Cisco capital and feels that product management isn't a priority. What started off as a strong product is slowly declining. Many competitors have begun to catch up or surpass AppDynamics. The sales organization lacks diversity and received the most perks. The current CEO is not focused on new product development but more so how to sell as much software as possible. Sales compensation is paid out 6 months later and is often incorrect even with the new automated system. Sales organization receives the majority of perks and funding to party and hold meaningless offsites.

main_text: I worked at AppDynamics full-time for more than a year

There is no work/life balance... you’ll be expected to work on the weekends (data entry and receive multiple emails with actions on a Sunday as an example) 

Managers manage down and have no idea how to manage up. 

Monkeys (managers) and robots (salespeople).

Product is not easy to sell, it’s hard to implement and very expensive, so if customers don’t have a consistent or huge application issue that impacts their business, they will not buy. This is a luck of the draw type of situation. Your territory may not have orgs with perceived big application issues and you will make no money while being micromanaged. 

Very stressful job

Cisco has taken over comp plans, so much harder to make money and they are over hiring so smaller territories. 

The wave has crashed

main_text: I have been working at AppDynamics full-time for less than a year
pros: High integrity team - Everyone I've met and worked with is a sincerely good person with good intentions. AppD only seems to hire great people. Extremely growth-oriented - From org-wide process focus to individual coaching, there's a lot of opportunity for growth. Widely Used Product - The core offering is widely used and unanimously valued—especially in the financial sector. It's good to know the work you're doing is ultimately impactful. Burgeoning User Focus - As an org with a product based in user pain points, they've spent many years focusing less on users than on putting out fires. The new product leadership is swinging the org back towards user needs with staffing and strategy which is exciting.
cons: Inspiration - The leadership team seems more focused on stability rather than inspiration. Which makes sense but from an employee perspective, it would be energizing to to be compelled forward rather than obliged. Lack of Prioritization - There are dozens of priorities in the product org. This seems to be remedying but it makes alignment difficult. Recruiting - Given the product is specific to a very specific market, it makes appealing to talent a little more challenging—especially non-technical talent.

cons: • I can’t believe that I am saying this but there are not enough restrooms in the office; there are lines at all hours of the day • Nobody seems like they get promoted • Non-technically minded people do have problems here - its a complex product • Company is pushing more “fun”, but management needs to realize that “fun” clashes with deadlines that they’ve imposed • Management needs to provide a list of prioritized strategies / goals and stick to them. Sometimes it feels like we have a moving target of prioritizations. • The company has decided to move to an “agile” environment (not only for product /engineering, but all departments), but there are no experienced agile SME’s on-staff – this is causing HUGE problems

The company itself is investing a lot of time and energy into the people who work here and the values it wants to uphold. All of those things have made coming to work that much more fulfilling. AppD has a collection of really smart, really humble, and really down-to-earth go-getters who not only want to put out a great product, but have a positive impact on the world (I know this sounds cliche but I've never been in a work environment where this is practiced more).
cons: There are a lot of moving parts within the company and sometimes it can be hard to know what's going on or who knows what. There also doesn't seem to be as much cross-functional team interaction--there's lots going on and teams tend to do social things within themselves but it'd be great to see more office-wide or company-wide events.

main_text: I have been working at AppDynamics full-time for more than a year
pros: While the work is challenging, the work place is fun. After the initial excitement settled down and through the IPO / acquisition changes, I still feel love to go to work . A female engineer, I feel I am very respected by my peers and my manager. Career path is clear to me. People here are always trying to make things fun, from a big holiday party to a bug bash. Even an engineer like me felt like to dress up to attend a grand holiday party held in SF City hall. In a bug bash, you can dress crazy and get a prize. The HRs would never miss any holidays or spirit days to throw a happy hour. There are daily fresh floral arrangements at the front desk and entrances on each floor. We have three-day hackathons, and this year we will have two! I worked on an AI project and an IoT project in past hackathons. None of these were related to my daily duty. How cool was that? The coolest thing is, if your project wins the top votes, besides award dollars you can demonstrate your project in AppSphere, a customer and partner conference usually held in cities like Las Vegas, London or New York, in front of a broad audience of more than two thousands! Besides badminton team, soccer team, cricket team, foosball tournaments, there are events and outings specifically for women organized or sponsored by the company's two women organizations: Women In Technology and Women In Engineering. Many female colleagues get opportunities to attend Grace Hopper Conference, or Google I/O, etc. Our parent company Cisco also has a global Women's Day conference. There are numerous things to mention, and numerous things to keep me excited everyday.

main_text: I worked at AppDynamics full-time for more than a year
pros: Growth - The company is growing at an amazing pace: sales, features, people. While this leads to growing pains it also means there are opportunities for professional growth and financial reward that aren’t available at most other companies. Can be a great stepping stone to other Silicon Valley companies. Product - The product is great and has a tremendous moat. Being able to see every line of code puts the company in a fantastic position with the ability to expand in numerous directions. There are multiple product lines using different tech so there is always something interesting to learn. People - Some really smart people to learn from in multiple areas. A lot of genuinely good and friendly people. The culture takes it’s toll though and few people actually seem happy with the company. Good diversity with different backgrounds and people from all over the world, better than your typical silicon valley company. Some teams are great, some teams should be avoided like the plague. Same for managers. Work life balance and work from home opportunities can be good. As with most places, the team and manager will make the difference.
cons: Culture - Zero transparency. A team gets hacked and it gets hushed up, no lessons learned. People leave and you never know why. Everything happens behind closed doors. Nothing is really data driven, just what senior people want. Communication is horrible, with people often ignoring direct emails. Management - Finger pointing is the norm. Bad mouthing and placing blame on other teams and subordinates is fairly common. Leaders are seldom held accountable for anything as long as they smile and tell the CEO what he wants to hear. Sycophants tend to be promoted with loyalty to your manager more important than loyalty to the company. Some managers won’t hesitate to lie or sabotage things to promote their agenda. Many mangers have no idea how to lead or help subordinates grow their careers. Political Grinder - Work hard, make an impact, have the credit taken by others. Politicians thrive by sweet talking the CEO/CTO and bashing others. Most the best people leave after a year or two (sometimes quicker) when they realize things won’t change and that loyalty to your manager is more important than the results you produce for the company. The endless stream of people who think this will change is a goldmine for the grinder though.

Even with a good run professionally with good teams, good projects, good pay, good people etc. AppDynamics has taken it all to another level. cons: The truth is - it's not worth joining AppDynamics, especially if you are UK based. The culture is nothing short of horrendous, borderline abusive. Management uses fear tactics on a daily basis, bullying employees to the point of burn-out. There is a high degree of favouritism, and the good accounts are selectively given to the clique. Forget about work life balance, really. No matter how resilient you think you are - nearly no one lasts for over 2 years. If you want to keep your sanity, avoid AppDynamics.

review_title: Still a good place to be, but don't believe it is a start up
main_text: I worked at AppDynamics full-time for more than 3 years
pros: AppD still has a great product that meets a genuine business need. With a decent account list, you will always make money. There are also excellent promotion / pay rise opportunities because there is such a high turnover of staff and management is desperate to positively spin this as a good thing meaning people are frequently promoted way above their capabilities. Good for the individual but some what self fulfilling as others then leave because they have managers with no experience, training or competency.
cons: The biggest issue with AppD is the fact the thought leadership has all but gone. The real engine that drove AppD forward and made it successful has left. Those who have come in after just blindly try to replicate other peoples ideas but lack the authenticity and understanding. There are also major issues behind the scenes with the product development and SaaS which is very poorly managed resulting in numerous issues for customers. There has been a massive loss of developers meaning product release keep slipping back and Cisco has prioritised integration into its portfolio over any genuine innovation. The brain drain also extends to the Sales and Sales Engineering teams. Huge name customers with massive lifetime spend are now being managed by very inexperienced reps who have no idea about the product, the company or how to get anything done. All up, AppD is still a good place to be, but it is not the rocket ship or start up people claim it to be. This is because the real A Players have long gone and those who have been recruited to back fill are just not of the same calibre.

review_title: Really proven themselves during difficult times

pros: Honestly, working at AppDynamics has been quite the rollercoaster. It's definitely not the same company it was in its start up phase, with many of the original senior leadership gone. That has its pros and cons. While the "old AppD" was hard going, with very poor work/life balance, and a culture to be proud of how far and hard you could push yourself, it was pretty much a baptism of fire. You were learning from the best how to be the best, if you were motivated by that then you come out the other side learning an unbelievable amount and having faster and better development into how to successfully and repeatedly run large enterprise software sales cycles. If you give it your all and persevere, management and leadership always have your back to the core. When things aren't working, they look at the data and find actual ways to improve, not empty suggestions to just "try harder". But make no mistakes, it is one of the hardest jobs you'll ever do. I've never known such a flat hierarchy structure where you're encouraged to engage with the global leadership team for your deals from early on in your career. Growth and development is paramount. That being said, I honestly can't say what it would be like for new hires now i feel the culture and training is very dependent on the individual managers continuing to drive the original culture. Finally, during Covid and the current uncertainty, AppD & Cisco have really proven themselves that they care. We're working from home, our safety is paramount. If you need to take time with your families it's encouraged. We had budget allocated to buy anything we needed to get our work from home set up . Business is still going well, but they are responding to what's happening in the world not shutting their eyes to it and pushing a business as usual agenda. The flat hierarchy leaves the communication between execs all the way through to new hires open.
cons: There's definitely uncertainty at the moment in where the business is going with Cisco. I would say if you're still looking for the hard really intense start up culture that AppD used to have then you may have missed the boat. If you're looking for somewhere that still has unparalleled sales training, with more of a corporate culture, and want to learn how to cross sell a platform across an organisation rather than a single tool to specific userbase, then this is the right choice.

review_title: Not what they promise, actively avoid
main_text: I have been working at AppDynamics full-time for more than a year
pros: The Boot Camp in San Fran is really fun, and the MEDDIC training is excellent, something I wish I had been taught when I started sales. The issue however, is that the people who teach it are now poor imitations of those who implemented it. The expense policy is pretty nice, however this is slowly being stamped out due to Cisco getting more involved. If you like to travel, then you get to book good flights and book your own hotels so you can build up reward points.
cons: The UK office has a horrifically toxic culture and feel to it. Within the Sales team the managers are borderline bullies, who seems to actively enjoy breaking people down and making them feel worthless. This may have worked in the past when the managers knew how to pick people up and help them improve, but this is no longer the case. You are lied to during the interview process. Nobody has had a $1m year for a few years, and I think only 1 person has had a $500k year in the last few years. The promise of rapid career progression is also a lie, people get promoted at the same rate as other large software companies now. You're given a list of accounts that have already had at least 2 or 3 people try and break into for several years, and then when you make no progress, you are simply told you need to do longer hours instead of getting actual advice or help. The general attitude is to survive a year and use the name on your CV to springboard into a better role in a different company. When people leave, it's like they never existed and are only spoken about when managers claim they weren't 'AppD material' and were fired for being useless, when this is often not the case.

review_title: if you’re in sales, stay away from this company unless...
main_text: I worked at AppDynamics full-time for more than a year
pros: The product is one of the best out there, as is the sales methodology. As a field sales you’re exposed to a variety of customers from different industries so you learn a lot.
cons: Unless you have no plans of having a life outside work for the foreseeable future, if you’re looking to join the EMEA sales org, beware! The sales “culture” is borderline bullying, unless you’re ok with becoming a micro-managed puppet and yes man. Middle Management is made of top performing individual contributors who are often the most arrogant and devoid of people skills. They are promoted without having a clue about what it means to lead a team of people, hence frustrating their team members while deferring any real decision to senior management. The sales floor is always full of tension and the everyday pressure is akin to what most organizations experience only at year end. There’s no room for disagreement and management thinks they’re always right. Unless you embrace anything they tell you and do what they say exactly how they went it and when they want it, you’re not coachable and therefore have a problem. This includes making up stories (I.e. lying blatantly) to push customers to meet you or to justify your sales tactics. You’re also expected to read and reply emails and even get on calls at any hour or the day, night and over the weekend, and overall use the weekend to think about your deals and plan for the week ahead. You’re discouraged from ever taking holidays and feel guilty when you eventually do (most likely you’ll end up working throughout them anyway). Management holds Cisco in very low regard instead of fostering collaboration with the mother company. They will also try to find ways to take deals or commission away from you if more convenient to them or if they want to teach you a lesson. There’s much more to say but by now you get the picture.
